title: Moche ceramic bottle depicting a lizard
description: The Moche dominated Peru’s north coast from about 100-750/800 CE. It is well known for its remarkable naturalistic, sculptural art style, tremendously diverse subject matter derived from at least four parallel worlds the Moche conceived, and its narrative (story-telling) character. This art style is unique in the New World and is renowned for the exceptional array of finely crafted pottery vessels with exquisite realism as this vessel (ca. 200-350 CE) illustrates. It depicts a lizard ready to leap. It has inlays of Spondylus shell on its back. Lizards are active during the day but also spend much of their life underground. Thus, in Moche art they are sometimes shown accompanying the solar deity as well as the dead. Dimension_____. MALI.

title: Moche ceramic bottle depicting a monkey
description: Both wild and domesticated animals from the natural world received a lot of attention and appeared in Moche sculptural renderings. As in the case of earlier Cupisnique art, known animals from the Amazon rainforest like the possible spider (Ateles sp.) or titi (Pitheciidae sp.) monkey may have been kept as exotic pets by the Moche. This vessel (ca. 250-350 CE) depicts a monkey climbing down from a tree branch.  Moche painted art on pottery is nearly always bichrome (dark red in cream or the converse) and complex motifs are typically executed in fine reddish lines as seen on this vessel. Changes in the form of stirrup spouts helped early investigators to determine the relative age of Moche vessels. Dimensions 18.6 cm high.

title: Moche effigy condor bottle
description: This captivating pottery vessel depicts an Andean condor (Vultur gryphus), one of the largest flying birds in the world (wingspan of up to ca. 3.3m). As a being from the natural world, it carries a much mythological significance in traditional Andean religions. Note the marvelous glossy finish and somewhat human-like expression on the bird’s face. Its diagnostic features such as a wattle on the neck and a large comb or caruncle on the crown of the head are well captured. Moche vessels such as these were formed using two-piece molds, one of the techniques for which their artisans are best known and which distinguishes them from others. Dimension ___. MBCR.

title: Large Moche ceramic jar
description: Moche artisans were exceptionally skilled at capturing the nuances of human form and expression. Object #38 (450-600 CE) is an intriguing example of their attention to detail. This vessel depicts an individual with a cleft palate and deformed nose. Unlike the modern conception of bodily imperfections, individuals with physical defects, religious people and shamans of the later Inca Empire were thought to be quite magical.  There are many examples of Moche ceramics depicting individuals with varied physical defects such as this. This individual is depicted holding what appear to be two gourd bowls in their right hand, and a shallow pottery bowl in the left, possibly containing medicinal roots or forming part of a healing ritual. The individual is shown wearing a simple head cover and ear ornaments, and a simply decorated shirt or tunic with classic step designs and simplified representations of metallic sequin-like adornments on the cuffs. Unlike the preceding fully sculptural examples, only the head of the individual is rendered in three-dimensional sculptural form. In this case, a combination of hand formation and partial molding techniques were used in its construction. Dimension ____. Huacas de Moche.

title: Moche ceramic bottle representing a seated deity
description: This vessel depicts an important anthropomorphic mythological being with large feline-like fangs wearing a head ornament that features a face of an owl. On his back, he wears what may be a feline pelage. Although the body is rendered in realistic form with regular human proportions, the face and his association with a feline and an owl suggests a mythological character of the being. Owl is frequently represented in the Moche art, both in its natural and anthropomorphic form. Owl as a nocturnal creature and raptorial in nature is often associated with the death (underworld) and the night. Some scholars consider this being as the principal Moche deity-cultural hero (see Object#40, 42 and 43). Perhaps he is preparing to make a trip to the underworld. Dimension 25.2 cm high. ML.

title: Moche ceramic bottle of deity as a manioc
description: The same mythological anthropomorphic being on Object #39 is depicted here with the stylized manioc root (Manihot sp.) body. Manioc was one of the staple food items of the Moche. The identity of this being as the principal Moche deity-cultural hero is quite clear from various ornaments and facial features including the bulging eyes, large fangs, feline-head ear ornaments. This vessel (400-550 CE) reveals some basic aspects of the Moche religion and cosmology; that the key deities can assume different forms depending on contexts and activities they engage in. It also informs us that the Moche religion was animistic, and that deities are found in all manner of things and beings. Dimension___. Huacas de Moche.

title: Moche black bottle of a bat decapitator
description: This ceramic bottle (450-550 CE) depicts a seated anthropomorphic mythological being that serves the role of decapitating sacrificed humans. Here, it holds a sacrificial knife, or tumi, in one hand, and a decapitated human head by its hair, in the other. This being has the head and wings as well as sharp fangs of what is believed to be a vampire bat. Thus, the being is sometimes called the Bat Demon or Bat Decapitator. As a nocturnal vampire bat, it carries symbolic significance of darkness and death. The shiny black finish is quite appropriate. Like earlier Cupisnique and later Sicán pots, these dark colored vessels were manufactured in oxygen depleted environments. The evenly placed dots originally had some mineral and/or shell inlays.  Dimension 25.0 cm high.  ML.

title: Moche ceramic model of a deity emerging out of a conch shell
description: A mythological episode of the heroic saga or “adventure” of the most prominent and important Moche deity has been variously called Deity F, Ai Paec or Deity with Serpent Belt. Regardless of the name we use, this anthropomorphic mythical being has various diagnostic features including (as you can see here) the bulging eyes, large fangs, feline head-shaped ear ornaments and a belt of double-headed serpent. He is frequently depicted emerging out of some plant (as in Object #40) or animal. But more importantly, he is shown battling dangerous monsters and evil forces of the Moche world (see below).   Here, he is shown emerging out of the marine mollusk Strombus (conch shell) carrying spears and spear throwers. Dimension ___. ML.

title: Moche black bottle showing a combat between a crab monster and a deity
description: This exquisite example of Moche black sculptural pottery illustrates a fierce battle between the Crab Monster (forefront) and the Deity with Serpent Belt. Among the different worlds of the Moche, the sea (Pacific) stands out as particularly perilous as it is inhabited by various dangerous monsters such as crab, ray and Strombus shell (conch – see the next object). Dimension___. MALI.

title: Moche painted flaring base with scenes of three battles
description: This is a partially reconstructed flaring rim bowl with a complex iconography on its interior that tells us the “adventure” or a sequence of battles that the Deity with Serpent Belt engaged in in the mythological world. In this scene, Ai Apaec appears to be the principal cultural hero or protagonist of the Moche mythology. He battles with the mythical being with a spherical body in one moment and with the Strombus (conch shell) Monster in another. We see a partial depiction of yet another battle with a Demonic Fish monster. Perhaps the Moche people conceived this deity to be the protector of their world and wellbeing. This vessel informs us that Moche art has a narrative character. Dimension 29.5 cm high. ML.

title: Moche black ceramic bottle depicting a duck 'warrior'
description: Among representational sculptural vessels of animals in the Moche world, this finely crafted reduce-fired bottle with shell inlay stands out for its expressive magical realism.  Like Object #46 that follows, the regal duck depicted here is a warrior. Rather unlike the frenetic mythical battle scene depicted on the interior of Object #44, the duck warrior waits resolutely for a call to battle. Dimension ___. Huacas de Moche.

title: Moche sculptural pottery of warrior
description: This kneeling man holding a square shield and a wooden war club and wearing large earspools and an elaborate head gear is an excellent example of three-dimensional Moche ceramic art. The man is rendered in fully human form, indicating his real-world role and status as an elite warrior. The individual appears to bear the insignia (alternating black-and-neutral pinwheel designs) on both shield and headdress. This vessel is remarkable for its attention to detail. Black and white embellishments are actually applied stone (or asphalt) ornaments that were carefully carved and adhered to the surface. The typical wooden club shown often with depictions of warriors was formed separately and added to the vessel after firing was complete. Dimension____. Huacas de Moche.

title: Moche ceramic  bottle showing Bird Warrior
description: This vessel (ca. 450-600 CE) depicts what is referred as the Bird Warrior, a relatively common subject in the Moche art. Like his human warrior counterparts, Bird Warrior wears a two-piece tunic and headdress, and carries typical warrior shield, darts, and war club.  In addition to metallic embellishments in the forms of tumi knives (crescent shaped) on his helmet and back-flap, small metallic plaques and discs have been sewn onto the tunic. Adding to his imposing presence, Bird Warrior’s wings are spread as if in preparation for flight. Note the curious cactus and fig-like decorations in the background of the scene. Far from being random decorations, they help us to define the Bird Warrior’s role as a sacrificer. While the cactus is likely to represent hallucinogenic San Pedro cactus (Echinopsis pachanoi), the fig-like fruits may be the magical ulluchu that appear in several Moche sacrifice scenes and may have been used as anticoagulants in sacrifice ceremonies. Dimension ___MNAAH.

title: Moche ceramic bottle representing a seated Bird Warrior
description: This vessel (450-600 CE) is a sculptural version of the Bird Warrior described in relation to the preceding object (Object #47). It is rich in artistic details it possesses; the warrior wears face, hand and foot paint as well as large earspools and an elaborate headdress adorned with a bat or feline. His pectoral is decorated with mythological double-headed snakes. However, he is not shown with bird wings as in the case of Object #47. It is probable that the seated individual is a human warrior wearing mask of a bird. There are Moche painted vessels that clearly show human warriors wearing a mask with a different bird head (e.g., with long, straight beak or a hooked beak) and a different head dresses who participate as runners in a race. It seems different warriors with different costumes raced on behalf of different sociopolitical or mythological groups. The individual on this vessel may be waiting for the start of the race. Dimension 23.0 cm high. ML.

title: Moche ceramic bottle depicting a woman with a 'living dead'
description: The blurring of the line between the worlds of the living and the dead is exquisitely rendered on this Moche ceramic bottle (ca. 450-700 CE). This vessel depicts a couple that while possibly united in life, were certainly united in death. The living figure embraces the dead who is playing a panpipe.  He seems dead from the neck up (sunken eyes, eroded nose and exposed- teeth), and appears life-like from the neck down. Still bearing the accoutrements of his status and possible role, including headdress and ear ornaments, the partially skeletonized individual still plays the pan-pipe as he would have in life. Through this simple representation, we see that the living and the dead continued to interact beyond the confines of human existence. Dimension_____. Huacas de Moche.

title: Moche ceramic bottle representing a sacrificial ritual atop a mountain
description: Careful analysis of the large corpus of Moche art indicates that one of the major themes of the Moche art is offering human sacrifices to the deities they worshipped or feared. The analysis also tells us that sacrifices were made at major mountains (at top or base) as shown in this vessel (ca. 400-500 CE) or on offshore islands (see Object #53). The dead body lying at the mountain base is believed to have been thrown from the mountain top to be sacrificed to the deity who inhabits the mountain. In the Andes, it is widely believed to this day that deities inhabit major mountains. The seated figure with an elaborate head-gear presumably supervised this sacrificial ritual. The smaller figures have fangs in their mouth and may represent assistants of the deity retrieving the sacrificed body.  Dimension 21.5 cm high. ML.

title: Moche ceramic bottle showing a warrior with a naked captive
description: How were live humans captured to be sacrificed? They were captured through armed combats. Warriors of two opposing groups fought face to face using war clubs, maces and shields. You have already seen that there are many Moche representations of warriors (e.g., Object #46, 55, 56). This vessel (ca. 350-450 CE) shows what happens after the combat; losers were denuded, their hairdos undone, and their hands were tied behind their backs as they were led away with a rope around the neck, eventually to be sacrificed. Dimension ____. Huacas de Moche.

title: Moche ceramic bottle illustrating a mythical navigation
description: This is a masterpiece of Moche “fine-lining” painting (ca. 500-550 C.E.) in its use of the available surface area, and the skill with which the central and surrounding motifs are composed, drawn and placed. This pottery was excavated from a tomb at the base of the Temple of the Moon at the site of Huacas de Moche, the capital of the Southern Moche polity. What is painted is the deity of the sea (Pacific) rowing his crescent-shaped reed boat loaded with a fishing net and two pots. Lively swimming fish and flying sea birds surround the boat, which probably symbolized the moon that traveled across the sky during the night. The painting effectively tells us of the critical importance of the marine resources and the Pacific for Moche life. Dimension 30.0 cm. Huacas de Moche.

title: Moche ceramic bottle representing a boat with a sacrificial victim
description: This intricate sculptural vessel (350-500 CE) represents a large reed boat in shape of a stylized tuna with a mythical being and two naked and tied human males. The mythical being with the prominent fangs and bulging eyes shown holding a split bamboo oar is the important Moche deity of the sea (Pacific). In terms of Moche cosmovision, this scene illustrates the deity taking the two sacrificial humans to an offshore island where the dead and the deity of the night and the Galaxy reside. The sea deity had a critical role of mediating the world of the living humans and the world of the dead. Dimension 22.3 cm high, 29.5 cm long. MBCR.

title: Moche ceramic jar in form of captured warrior
description: Moche potters produced many vessels such as this jar that depicts a warrior who lost in combat, was captured and brought from the battle field (note the rope around the neck) to be sacrificed. Note that he has facial paintings and wears large ear ornaments, all readily recognizable markers of high status.  Examination of preserved skeletal remains of the sacrificed warriors has shown that they were all young, robust, adult males. Many were badly mutilated, apparently to show as much blood as possible. Moche art shows mythical scenes of a priestess offering a cup of human blood to an important deity. Dimension___. MBCR.

title: Moche ceramic bottle representing a warrior
description: This sculptural Moche pottery depicts a kneeled warrior holding a mace ready to engage in combat. Note the elaborate head gear he wears. It appears that the head gear was a highly visible marker of wearer’s status, role and/or sociopolitical affiliation. Many headdresses bear representations of what appear to be the patron deity and/or powerful mythical creature (e.g., feline), that may indicate clan affiliation as well. Dimension___. MNAAH.

title: Moche pottery of a warrior leader meeting a subordinate
description: This is a magnificent, black sculptural ceramic bottle (ca. 500-550 CE) shows a high-status warrior-leader holding a shield and a mace in his hands. He is seated atop a dais as he meets another warrior.  The gulf that separates these two individuals is made apparent by a notable difference in their sizes. Moche artists employed a widely adopted practice of depicting the principal subject disproportionately large, elevated and at the center of our vision. An atlatl (a device used to throw darts farther) is placed next to the left foot of the leader. Inlays are made of shell (white), turquoise (light blue) and asphalt (black). Dimension___. Huacas de Moche.
